He previously served as [[Leader of the Opposition (United Kingdom)|Leader of the Opposition]] from 2020 to 2024. He has been [[Member of Parliament (United Kingdom)|Member of Parliament]] (MP) for [[Holborn and St Pancras (UK Parliament constituency)|Holborn and St Pancras]] since 2015, and was [[Director of Public Prosecutions (England and Wales)|Director of Public Prosecutions]] from 2008 to 2013. Born in London and raised in [[Surrey]], Starmer attended [[Reigate Grammar School]]. He was active politically as a teenager, and graduated with a [[Bachelor of Laws]] degree from the [[University of Leeds]] in 1985 and received a postgraduate [[Bachelor of Civil Law]] [[Master's degree|degree]] from the [[University of Oxford]] where he was a student at [[St Edmund Hall, Oxford|St Edmund Hall]] in 1986. After being [[called to the Bar]], Starmer practised predominantly in criminal defence work, specialising in [[human rights]]. He served as a human rights adviser to the [[Northern Ireland Policing Board]], [[taking silk]] as a [[Queen's Counsel]] in 2002. During his tenure as [[Director of Public Prosecutions]] and [[Crown prosecutor|Head]] of the [[Crown Prosecution Service]] he dealt with a number of major cases, including the [[Murder of Stephen Lawrence|Stephen Lawrence murder case]]. In the [[2014 New Year Honours]], he was appointed a [[Knight Commander of the Order of the Bath]] (KCB) for "services to law and criminal justice". Starmer's policing work in Northern Ireland influenced him to pursue a political career, and he was elected to the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] at the [[2015 United Kingdom general election|2015 general election]]. He supported the Remain campaign in the [[2016 European Union membership referendum]] and advocated a [[Proposed referendum on the Brexit withdrawal agreement|proposed second referendum on Brexit]]. He served in [[Jeremy Corbyn]]'s Shadow Cabinet as [[Shadow Brexit Secretary]], and following Corbyn's resignation after Labour's defeat at the [[2019 United Kingdom general election|2019 general election]], Starmer succeeded him by winning the [[2020 Labour Party leadership election (UK)|2020 leadership election]]. As Leader of the Opposition he moved Labour towards the [[political centre]] and emphasised the elimination of [[Antisemitism in the British Labour Party|antisemitism within the party]], and his party made significant gains in the [[2023 United Kingdom local elections|2023]] and [[2024 United Kingdom local elections|2024 local elections]]. Starmer oversaw a significant drop in Labour membership in the years leading up to the 2024 election. Starmer led Labour to a [[landslide victory]] at the [[2024 United Kingdom general election|2024 general election]], ending fourteen years of [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] governance, though with the smallest electoral vote share of any majority government since record-keeping of the popular vote began [[1830 United Kingdom general election|in 1830]]. Under [[Premiership of Keir Starmer|Starmer's premiership]] the government has ended certain [[winter fuel payment]]s for around 10 million people, implemented an early-release scheme for thousands of prisoners to decrease prison overcrowding, and settled a number of [[United Kingdom industrial disputes and strikes (2022–present)|public-sector strikes]]. Starmer has announced the [[Border Security Command]] in replacement of the [[Rwanda asylum plan]] and a National Violent Disorder Programme in response to the [[2024 United Kingdom riots|2024 riots]], as well as reforms to [[workers' rights]]. In foreign policy, he [[United Kingdom and the Russian invasion of Ukraine|has supported Ukraine in the Russia-Ukraine war]] and [[British support for Israel in the Israel–Hamas war|Israel in the Israel-Hamas war]], whilst also calling for a ceasefire. == Early life and education == [[File:Reigate Grammar School.jpg|left|thumb|[[Reigate Grammar School]] (pictured 2009), where Starmer was a pupil]] Keir Rodney Starmer was born on 2 September 1962, at [[Southwark]] in south east London,{{Who's Who |author=Anon |title=Starmer, Rt Hon. |url-status=dead |archive-date=23 February 2015 |title=People of Today |publisher=Debretts.com |access-date=4 July 2016}} == Legal career == {{Main|Legal career of Keir Starmer}} === Barrister === Starmer became a [[barrister]] in 1987 at the [[Middle Temple]], then a [[bencher]] in 2009. He served as a legal officer for the campaign group [[Liberty (advocacy group)|Liberty]] until 1990. Starmer was a member of [[Doughty Street Chambers]] from 1990 onwards, primarily working on human rights matters. Starmer has been [[called to the Bar]] in several [[Caribbean Community|Caribbean countries]],{{cite web |url=https://www.middletemple.org.uk/bencher-persons-view?cid=32311 |title=Middle Temple |website=Middle Temple |access-date=4 January 2020 |archive-date=26 September 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200926134509/https://www.middletemple.org.uk/bencher-persons-view?cid=32311 |url-status=live}} where he defended convicts sentenced to the death penalty. In 1999 he was a junior barrister on [[Lee Clegg]]'s [[appeal]].{{Cite web |last=Seymour |first=Richard |date=28 April 2022 |title=Tell us who you really are, Keir Starmer |url=https://www.newstatesman.com/ideas/2022/04/tell-us-who-you-really-are-keir-starmer |access-date=1 July 2024 |website=New Statesman |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240615183726/https://www.newstatesman.com/ideas/2022/04/tell-us-who-you-really-are-keir-starmer |archive-date=15 June 2024}} Starmer assisted [[Helen Steel]] and David Morris in the [[McLibel case]], at the trial and appeal in English courts, also representing them before the [[European Court of Human Rights]].{{cite web |date=16 January 2020 |title=Corrections and clarifications |url=http://www.theguardian.com/news/2020/jan/16/corrections-and-clarifications |access-date=22 November 2022 |website=The Guardian |archive-date=13 February 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230213000001/https://www.theguardian.com/news/2020/jan/16/corrections-and-clarifications |url-status=live}} Starmer was appointed [[Queen's Counsel]] on 9 April 2002, aged 39.{{London Gazette |issue=56538 |date=16 April 2002 |page=4622}} In the same year, he became joint head of Doughty Street Chambers. In 2005 Starmer said "I got made a Queen's Counsel, which is odd since I often used to propose [[Republicanism in the United Kingdom|the abolition of the monarchy]]".{{cite web |title=Starmer embraces the Monarchy |url=https://www.camdennewjournal.co.uk/article/starmer-embraces-the-monarchy |website=[[Camden New Journal]] |access-date=23 May 2024 |archive-date=17 June 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240617065054/https://www.camdennewjournal.co.uk/article/starmer-embraces-the-monarchy |url-status=live}} Starmer authored legal opinions and marched in protest against the [[Iraq War]] following the [[2003 invasion of Iraq]], stating in 2015 that he believed that the war was "[[Legality of the Iraq War|not lawful under international law]] because there was no UN resolution expressly authorising it".{{Cite news |last=Starmer |first=Keir |date=30 November 2015 |title=Airstrikes in Syria are lawful, but I'll be voting against them |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2015/nov/30/syria-airstrikes-legal-david-cameron-civil-war-flawed |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200410171423/https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2015/nov/30/syria-airstrikes-legal-david-cameron-civil-war-flawed |archive-date=10 April 2020 |access-date=10 April 2020 |work=The Guardian}} Starmer served as a [[Human rights defender|human rights adviser]] to the [[Northern Ireland Policing Board]] and the [[Association of Chief Police Officers]], and was also a member of the [[Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office]]'s [[Capital punishment|Death Penalty]] Advisory Panel from 2002 to 2008. The Northern Ireland Board was an important part of bringing communities together following the [[Good Friday Agreement]], and Starmer later cited his work on policing in Northern Ireland as being a key influence on his decision to pursue a political career: "Some of the things I thought that needed to change in police services we achieved more quickly than we achieved in strategic litigation... I came better to understand how you can change by being inside and getting the trust of people".{{Cite web |title=About Keir Starmer – MP for Holborn and St Pancras and Labour Leader |url=https://keirstarmer.com/about-keir/ |access-date=15 June 2024 |website=Keir Starmer |language=en-GB |archive-date=17 June 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240617065612/https://keirstarmer.com/about-keir/ |url-status=live}} Starmer represented [[Croatia]] at the genocide hearings before the [[International Court of Justice]] at [[The Hague]] in 2014, arguing that Serbia wanted to seize a third of Croatian territory during the 1990s war and eradicate the Croatian population.{{Cite web |last=Ivanovic |first=Josip |date=7 March 2014 |title=Serbia 'Tried to Eradicate Croatian Population' |url=https://balkaninsight.com/2014/03/07/serbia-tried-to-eradicate-croatian-population/ |website=Balkan Transitional Justice}} === Director of Public Prosecutions === [[File:DPP Keir Starmer in 2009 (cropped).jpg|thumb|upright=0.75|Official portrait as [[Director of Public Prosecutions (England and Wales)|Director of Public Prosecutions]], 2009]] In July 2008 [[Patricia Scotland]], [[Attorney General for England and Wales]], named Starmer as the new Head of the [[Crown Prosecution Service]] (CPS) and [[Director of Public Prosecutions (England and Wales)|Director of Public Prosecutions]] (DPP). He succeeded [[Ken Macdonald]], who publicly welcomed Starmer's appointment, on 1 November 2008. Starmer was deemed to be bringing a focus on human rights into the legal system. In 2011 he introduced reforms that included the "first test paperless hearing".{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/law/2011/dec/02/lawyers-with-laptops-crown-prosecution-service dealt with a number of major cases including the [[Murder of Stephen Lawrence|Stephen Lawrence murder case]], where he brought his murderers to justice.{{cite web |access-date=5 January 2012 |archive-date=21 January 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120121234510/http://blog.cps.gov.uk/2011/05/joint-cpsmps-statement-on-stephen-lawrence-case-.html |date=18 May 2011
